intro: Luzula spicata var. glomerata, commonly known as clustered wood sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant is characterized by its triangular, grass-like leaves and produces dense, spike-like clusters of small, greenish flowers. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it a valuable component of ecological restoration projects and a subject of study in plant morphology and taxonomy.
